main.text: time skip to when Member 2 is done talking

main.speaker: Member 2
main.text: Alright, so that was my introduction, and now we'll talk about the history of math.

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Thank you Member 2! So, as mentioned, I'll talk about the history of math.
slide change

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Let's get into it. Who knows who this is?
pause

main.speaker: Player
main.text: I see a few hands! This is Isaac Newton, who we know invented calculus
slide change

main.speaker: Player
main.text: But math finds its roots much further back in time

main.speaker: Player
main.text: All the way back to ancient Egypt and Babylon, around 2000 BC
slide change

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Math back then was very simple, mostly just numbers and counting

main.speaker: Player
main.text: You can see how this looked back then in these images

main.speaker: Player
main.text: It was mostly used for things like measuring things, time and angles

main.speaker: Player
main.text: It was also used for more complex things like geographical coordinates
slide change

main.speaker: Player
main.text: If we skip forward in time, we'll start to see names we recognize a little more

main.speaker: Player
main.text: You may have heard of a couple of these names

main.speaker: Player
main.text: We have Pythagoras, who of course invented the Pythagorean theroem

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Archimedes, who studied buoyancy

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Euclid, who is also very important to our math even today

main.speaker: Player
main.text: And a few other people who are shown here
slide change

main.speaker: Player
main.text: The next person I will talk about was alive around 780 tto 850 AD

main.speaker: Player
main.text: If you see this person's name, it might sound like a word you may know

main.speaker: Player
main.text: His name, when westernized, is 'algorithm'

main.speaker: Player
main.text: He is widely considered the father of algebra

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Which is a basis of a lot of the math we do today
slide change

main.speaker: Player
main.text: This is Leornado of Pisa, who brought arabic numerals to Europe

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Another name he has been referred to by is Fibonacci
slide change

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Let's jump ahead a lot, around the period of 1500 to 1700

main.speaker: Player
main.text: This period showed a lot of significant leaps in mathematics

main.speaker: Player
main.text: There are many notable people during this time who progressed mathematics

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Some of them are Galileo, Descartes, Pascal and Fermat

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Galileo is known as the father of modern science

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Descarte, of course, invented Cartesian geometry

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Finally, Fermat invented Fermat's last theorem
slide change

main.speaker: Player
main.text: I showed you Isaac Newton earlier, but he's back now, in the late 1600s

main.speaker: Player
main.text: Newton's contributions to mathematics and science are very important

main.speaker: Player
main.text: As I mentioned earlier he is best known for the creation of calculus

main.speaker: Player
main.text: As we move further and further ahead in time, we will continue to see more important people

main.speaker: Player
main.text: One of these people is Euler, who was one of the most prominent mathematicians of the 18th century

main.speaker: Player
main.text: A couple of honorable mentions are John von Neumann and Calude Shannon

main.speaker: Player
main.text: In addition to mathematics, they also did work that is the basis of computer science
slide change

main.speaker: Player
main.text: That's it from me, and my partner here will take over now
